title: You obviously don't want people using chat.
body:
So just remove it already. 

Or put all the little thin-skinned SJW babies in their own chat channel so they can complain about toxicity and create issues on their own. Let reasonable, non-insane people talk and be unhappy with things without fear of being punished for using trigger words or making the brats feel insecure.

And, let me tell you a secret: You ***CANNOT*** ruin a game with chat. Normal people (AKA, not obsessive to the point of insanity) don't even care what people on the internet say. What ruins games is trolls, your horrible matching system, your greed-driven balance, and so on. Could fix those instead of policing chat which is irrelevant.

Hell, we should censor half the champs too.

replies.body:
Or, hear me out here,

Riot could expect people to be normal, decent human beings, and when they aren't, remove them from interacting with other human beings.

Or, hear me out here,

Riot could know that competitive games, EVEN PROFESSIONAL SPORTS, go hand in hand with frustration. But that's just silly talk.
Or, they could expect you to use methods of releasing your frustration that don't affect other people?

Wanna know one of the most common methods of venting? Yelling out loud, or some other noise. 

Now, translate that into a video game. You "talk" with a keyboard, right? So, instead of yelling out loud, you type out loud.

> [{quoted}](name=SecondAirbane,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=3Tg8Eedm,comment-id=00000000000000000001000000000000,timestamp=2017-08-20T12:48:47.569+0000)

What is a false dichotomy?

I'd rather have someone who can show a sense of subtlety and self control instead of throw it on everyone else. I mean if that type of player wants to lose and make the team lose with it, that's just how it'll go.

You know the concept of ejection in baseball? The concept of a card in soccer?

Yeah. That's the concept of a ban in League of Legends. You can't go around on the playing field verbally abusing people.

If you can't healthily deal with frustration, you are by definition unsportsmanlike. Unsportsmanlike players are generally not permitted to play sports.

Whoever said I was verbally abusing anyone? It's like you stub your toe or something and yell about it to no one in particular. Not abusing anyone -- you might be annoying, but that's about the extent of it.

Now, imagine if we threw you in jail for doing that.
If you keep screaming about your toe, you'll be asked to stop. If you don't stop, you'll be removed from the public environment.

It's not that Riot doesn't want people using chat, it's that they (and the community as a whole in general) don't want people using it to verbally abuse and harass other players. It's definitely possible to use chat to communicate with your team as well as have general conversations with them as well, but if you can't use chat without insulting other players then the problem is you and no one elses and you deserve to be held accountable for your poor behavior. Yes trolls are a problem, but proving intent is trickier than simple chat related offenses.

Bottom line: both are a problem and both need to be handled the right way, but it's not as simple as some make it out to be. if you disagree with Riot's behavioral rules then feel free to go to a game that has rules more to your liking.

People who actually ruin games (for example, there was a guild in WoW dedicated to crashing the world servers for somewhere around four years before I quit the game, nothing happened) go unpunished, but SJWs have their way with chat all the time.

If no one on the internet cares what you say, and will completely ignore you...why type anything at all?

If you, a reasonable, non-insane person gets upset with a game and wants to cry, whine and insult people....wait...

That line doesn't work very well. Why would a normal person throw a temper tantrum? That sounds more like the 'babies' insult you threw out there earlier.

People, no matter how old they are or how mature they are, are vulnerable to this thing called frustration. And then there's this thing called venting that people typically do, right?

Kind of a common thing.

True, the issue is that you are venting by  making the experience of others worse.

Find a way to vent that doesn't make a complete ass out of yourself. Yell at your screen, play a funny 30 second youtube clip, put a ball on your desk to throw, get a friggen fidget spinner idc, just keep it out of the game.

you say "dont make a complete ass out of yourself" yet all the "solutions" you described are ways to make a complete ass of yourself

and please lets be real here if we're frustrated do you honestly think we're gonna laugh ?

It will relieve stress.

And none of those things are making a negative impact on your team.

1: no just no its stupid as fuck

2: how the fuck is complaining about a champion a negative experience

1 - It's not stupid, it's actually effective.

- Yelling (shouting, cursing, etc; vocally expelling) helps to burn out anger and pain, so it can work as a form of stress-relief. (seriously, go look up _Mythbusters - No Pain, No Gain_, they've tested it.)
- Watching funny things (or endearing things, whatever makes you happy) lightens your mood and makes you less negative, which, again, relieves stress. It can also help you distract yourself from the negative experience of the game, which further helps.
- Physical distractions are also equally therapeutic (throwing a ball at a wall, squeezing a stress ball, screwing around with a fidget spinner, etc.), and so, lo and behold, relieve stress.

Typing, however, does not relieve stress, as all you're doing is channeling that negativity into a chat pane, not actually doing much if anything to alleviate it. Which, also, helps even less if the stressor is still there.

---

2 - Some people don't like when others complain about stuff, and believe it or not, emotions, even through text, where there is no emotional inflection, spread like a plague. When you type out all your frustrations with X champion or whatever, you're liable to spread that negative attitude to your teammates.

And when your teammates catch your negativity, they play worse, which, who would've guessed? Creates a negative experience.

Nobody's expecting you to laugh when you get frustrated; everyone deals with frustration, we understand it, but we don't want any Debbie-Downers spreading their negativity and impacting our performance.

If you want to complain, go find somebody that you know will listen; you can burn out to them, but do not expect strangers to want to listen to your ineffective venting.
